title: 115_s2288
content: The "Veterans, Employees, and Taxpayers Protection Act of 2017" or the "VET Protection Act of 2017" amends Chapter 7 of title 38, United States Code, by adding a new subchapter on labor management in the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "VET Protection Act of 2017" amends Chapter 7 of title 38, United States Code by adding a new subchapter on labor management in the Department of Veterans Affairs. It includes provisions for tracking and reporting the use of official time by employees, ensuring accurate accounting without estimates or ranges of time. Annual reports must be submitted to the Office of Personnel Management and the Committees on Veterans' Affairs detailing the total official time granted and expended by employees. The "VET Protection Act of 2017" requires the Department of Veterans Affairs to track and report the use of official time by employees for various activities such as negotiations, labor-management relations, and dispute resolution. The reports must include details on the total official time expended, specific purposes for which official time was granted, number of employees granted official time, and details on salary and job title of employees granted official time. The Department of Veterans Affairs must track and report the use of official time by employees for activities like negotiations and labor-management relations. Official time is defined as periods granted to employees to perform representational functions while in duty status. Limitations are placed on using official time for political activities. Employees at the Department of Veterans Affairs are restricted in their use of official time for political or lobbying activities. Certain employees, including those appointed under specific sections, those with high pay rates, and those on probation, are prohibited from using official time. Other employees are limited to using no more than 25% of their duty time on official time. The term 'official time' is defined in section 751(c) of the title. Employees at the Department of Veterans Affairs can terminate voluntary dues allotments for payment at any time, as stated in the exclusive bargaining agreement. This provision applies to collective bargaining agreements before or after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. REQUIRED PROBATIONARY PERIOD FOR NEW EMPLOYEES OF DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. New employees at the Department of Veterans Affairs must serve a two-year probationary period before their appointment becomes final. This applies to permanent positions in the competitive service and career appointees in the Senior Executive Service at the Department. Employees at the Department of Veterans Affairs must complete a two-year probationary period for their appointment to become final. Supervisors must make a determination 90 days before the probationary period ends, based on regulations set by the Secretary. Amendments to related sections of title 5 are also made. Amendments to title 5 include inserting a new item after section 717. Amendments to Title 5, United States Code, include adding individuals covered by section 718 of Title 38 to various sections. Section 718 of Title 38, United States Code, is added to various sections of Title 5, United States Code. This applies to covered employees appointed after the enactment of the Act.
